title: Credit Suisse tips US infrastructure boom
text:
But the financial returns from making a buyout were enhanced with rates at such low levels.

"I do think lower interest rates help,'' he said.

Mr Eldredge said investors around the world were increasingly eyeing the opportunities which would come as the US played catch-up on much-needed spending on roads, bridges and rail projects.

He said some states were already getting on the front foot with special taxes because of wrangling over which arm of government should fund the spending.

"A lot of investors around the world are in tune with the US infrastructure need. Australian companies with exposure will benefit."

Of the ASX-listed building materials stocks, Boral, which acquired the Headwaters business in the US in 2016, and James Hardie Industries have the largest exposure to the American economy.

"The US has under-invested in infrastructure over the last few decades.''

The looming 2020 US presidential election would likely give an extra spotlight to creaking infrastructure and the need for a significant injection of funds, he said.

"There is a growing concern, and a growing consensus among the US people there needs to be a big infrastructure spend,'' he said.

Mr Eldredge didn't want to comment specifically on the prospects for individual Australian construction materials stocks.

But he said there had been ''an impressive snap back'' in the share price performance of many US-listed stocks as entry-level homebuyers began returning to the real estate market in 2019.

Credit Suisse's head of industrials in its Australian investment banking team, Stephen Pickles, said there was more caution in the Australian market compared with the US.

"It feels like the US market is a little more positive on the outlook than Australia,'' Mr Pickles said.

Australia was a highly consolidated market in building materials compared with the US which was still highly fragmented, he said.

Industry observers suggest that Boral Ltd is the most likely candidate for a takeover bid because it has been the biggest underperformer and been unable to convert Australia's own infrastructure boom into bottomline profit growth.

One of the other potential deals in Australia – that of a merger between Australia's biggest cement group Adelaide Brighton and privately owned Victorian concrete and quarry operator Barro Group which already owns 43 per cent of Adelaide Brighton – now has an extra complication with the competition regulator looking at the duo.

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission on October 25 revealed it had begun an investigation into whether Barro Group's stake in Adelaide Brighton is having an impact on competition between the firms in the marketplace.

The biggest area of focus by the competition regulator is on the supply of ready-mix concrete in Melbourne, where Barro Group runs brands including Pronto Concrete and Geelong Premixed Concrete.
description: Australian building materials companies with exposure to the US should get a kick along, although more M&A is looming.
